elements.content: Four nickel(II)-5-aminodiacetic isophthalate coordination polymers with different auxiliary ligands are synthesized by the solvothermal method. {[Ni4(adip)2(H2O)10]·6H2O} n (1) (H4adip = 5-aminodiacetic isophthalic acid) is a supermolecular structure assembled by two-dimensional (2D) layers, and it can be viewed as a novel binodal (3,4)-connected topological net with a Schläfli symbol of (4.6.8)4(62.82.102) which has not been reported in the literature. When dipyridyl auxiliary ligands with different spacers are engaged in the reactions to pillar the 2D layers of 1, the 3D frameworks of complexes 2–4 are obtained. {[Ni3(Hadip)2(bpy)2(H2O)4]·9H2O} n (2) (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine) was crystallographically characterized to be a three-dimensional (3D) coordination network with SPC519 type topology. {[Ni8(adip)4(bpy)(H2O)18]·10H2O} n (3) as a 3D framework exhibits a scarcely reported (3,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of (4.6.8)4(62.86.102). {[Ni2(adip)(bpp)(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (4) (bpp = 1,3-bis (4-pyridyl)propane) features a 3D chiral framework composed of the achiral reagents adip4– and bpp, resulting a new (4.52)(4.53.72.84) topology. Meanwhile, the influences of configuration and length of the auxiliary ligands on the structures are investigated. The magnetic studies indicate antiferromagnetic behaviors for complexes 1 and 3, and as their metal–metal distances in the dinulcear units increase the antiferromagnetic interactions become stronger.

elements.content: Four novel nickel(II)-5-aminodiacetic isophthalate coordination polymers with different auxiliary ligands are reported. The influences of configuration and length of the auxiliary ligands on the structures are investigated. Their magnetic studies indicate antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ni(II) centers.

elements.content: Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted more and more attention to this rapidly growing field due to their intriguing architectures and potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, luminescence, magnetism, and so on. Metal–organic frameworks exhibit diversified structures because the coordination geometry of the selected metal ions, the bridging modes of the organic ligands adopted, counterions, templates, and the reaction conditions such as temperature, solvent, pH value, and the ratio between metal salts and ligands exert crucial influences on the construction of the final results. The rational design and synthesis of compounds with desired architectures and promising properties are still a great challenge for chemists.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted more and more attention to this rapidly growing field due to their intriguing architectures and potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, luminescence, magnetism, and so on. Metal-organic frameworks exhibit diversified structures because the coordination geometry of the selected metal ions, the bridging modes of the organic ligands adopted, counterions, templates, and the reaction conditions such as temperature, solvent, pH value, and the ratio between metal salts and ligands exert crucial influences on the construction of the final results. The rational design and synthesis of compounds with desired architectures and promising properties are still a great challenge for chemists.

elements.content: So far, most of research efforts have been devoted to MOFs assembled by rigid polycarboxylate ligands owing to their rich coordination modes and the rational synthesis of default structures. The flexible iminodiacetate ligand has also achieved success in the construction of interpenetrating nets and the high-nuclearity metal clusters, since the flexibility of above ligand plays an important role in the design and synthesis of the final products. The ligands involving both rigid and flexible attributes are likely to be candidates for component parts of multifunctional materials, but they are not extensively investigated. The flexible iminodiacetic acid substituted isophthalic acid and terephthalic acid ligands have been employed in the syntheses of hybrid organic–inorganic materials; however, only a few chains and low-dimensional structures have been obtained up to now. The investigation of three-dimensional (3D) frameworks based on these types of ligands, which are probably more desirable for the realization of multifunctional materials, is still underway.

elements.content: The 5-aminodiacetic isophthalic acid (H4adip) possesses the rigid isophthalic acid moiety and the flexible iminodiacetic acid functionality, which exhibits a great variety of coordination modes. We found that it is quite difficult to build the 3D frameworks of coordination complexes only by the H4adip ligand due to its chelation of iminodiacetate moiety. Thus, the dipyridyl-type auxiliary ligands with different lengths are employed here to facilitate the formation of 3D structures. In this paper, a series of MOFs with diverse novel topologies including one two-dimensional (2D) complex {[Ni4(adip)2(H2O)10]·6H2O} n (1) and three 3D complexes {[Ni3(Hadip)2(bpy)2(H2O)4]·9H2O} n (2), {[Ni8(adip)4(bpy)(H2O)18]·10H2O} n (3), and {[Ni2(adip)(bpp)(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (4) are reported.

elements.content: The H4adip was prepared according to the literature. The other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Rigaku DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Magnetic data were obtained with a Quantum Design MPMS XL SQUID magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The H4adip was prepared according to the literature. The other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Rigaku DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Magnetic data were obtained with a Quantum Design MPMS XL SQUID magnetometer.

elements.content: A mixture of H4adip (0.2 mmol, 60 mg), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 297 mg), NaOH (0.2 mmol, 8 mg), THF (5 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 120 °C, and held at the temperature for 96 h. The autoclave was allowed to cool to 30 °C for 24 h. Pale green crystals of complex 1 were collected in 65.2% yield based on H4adip. Anal. Calcd for C24H24N3O12Ni2 (M r = 663.79): C, 25.96%; H, 4.14%; N, 2.52%. Found: C, 25.80%; H, 4.22%; N, 2.35%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3314 (s), 2018 (w), 1846 (w), 1735 (w), 1567 (vs), 1447 (s), 1410 (vs), 1219 (m), 1126 (br), 1060 (s), 944 (m), 780 (m), 719 (m).

elements.content: All the structures data of complexes 1–4 were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All of the structures were resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms except free water moleculers O32, O33 atoms in 1, O11, O12 (O12′), O13 (O13′), O14 (O14′), O15 atoms in 3 were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules and carboxylic groups were found in the electron density map and refined by riding except those belonging to free water molecule O31 (O31′) atom in 3, coordinated water molecules in 1, and all the water molecules in 2 and 4, which cannot be found. The other hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined by riding. O32 and O33 in 1, O15 in 2, and O11 in 4 possess the occupancy of 0.5. Three free water molecules (O12, O12′; O13, O13′; O14, O14) in 2 and one free water molecule (O31, O31′) are disordered and are refined using O atoms split over two equivalent sites with a total occupancy of 1. The absolute structure of the 4 has been determined with the Flack parameter of 0.002(16). Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for complexes 1–4 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in . More details on the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given in as CIF files. Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC reference numbers 806075–806078 for complexes 1–4.

elements.clean_text: 1  The Coordination Modes of H4adip Ligands in Complexes 1-4

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in a triclinic P1̅ space group. As illustrated in Figure , the asymmetric unit is composed of 4 independent Ni(II) cations, 2 kinds of adip4– anions, 10 aqua ligands, and 6 free water molecules in a crystal lattice. All the metal centers are six-coordinated in octahedral geometry. The two types of adip4– ligands, which adopt two different coordination modes A and B, respectively (Scheme ), are named La and Lb. La acts as a 5-coordinated μ5-ligand to link five metal centers. The two rigid isophthalic carboxylic groups of La are coordinated in two different modes (monodentate and bidentate in a syn-syn mode), while the flexible iminodiacetate moiety chelates one metal cation (Ni3) and connects to another one (Ni4) via a syn-anti carboxylate bridge mode. In contrast with La, both the rigid carboxylic groups of Lb are monodentate-coordinated, and the flexible iminodiacetic group adopts a carboxylic anti-anti mode bridging two metal centers (Ni1 and Ni2). The remaining coordination sites of the metal centers are occupied by water molecules. Interestingly, a μ2-bridging water molecule appears in the structure and joins Ni2 and Ni4 together combining with the carboxylic bridge (O11–C14–O12) of La. The metal–metal distance in the dinuclear unit is 3.666 Å. Two adjacent asymmetric units are linked to an octanuclear building block Ni8(adip)4(H2O)20 in a head-to-tail mode through the carboxylic bridge of the iminodiacetate group of La. La further connects the octanuclear building blocks to form a one-dimensional (1D) chain (Figure a). The parallel chains are cross-linked into a 2D wave-like layer by the linker of Lb (Figure b). Practically, the asymmetric units are linked into a 2D wave-like layer by the symmetric operation of inversion. Weak intermolecular π–π stacking interactions between the aryl moieties of La further assemble the 2D layers into a 3D supermolecular architecture. There are also intramolecular π–π stacking interactions between the phenyl of Lb in the layers (Figure c). Interestingly, the free aqua molecules in the crystal lattice form an infinite water chain along the a-axis.

elements.content: To best understand the structure of complex 1, the topology analysis is employed to describe the architecture. The isophthalate moiety of the H4adip and the iminodiacetate group involving the metal cations (Ni1 and Ni3) chelated by them are considered three-connected nodes, while the dinuclear unit (Ni2 and Ni4) is regarded as a four-connected node. The structure of 1 can be simplified as a novel binodal (3,4)-connected topological net with a Schläfli symbol of (4.6.8)4(62.82.102) (Figure d). Up to now, this new topology has not been reported in the literature.

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic C2/c space group. In the asymmetrical unit, there are one and half Ni atoms, one Hadip3– ligand, one bpy ligand, two coordination aqua molecules, and five and half free water molecules. Both metal cations, Ni1 and Ni2 are six-coordinated in a slightly distorted octahedral environment. Hadip3– ligands adopt coordination mode C to connect four metal centers (Scheme ). As shown in Figure , Ni1 is chelated by a Hadip3– ligand via its iminonitrogen (N1) and two oxygen atoms (O1 and O3) from the two iminocarboxylate arms respectively. The remaining three face-related coordination sites are occupied by O5A from another Hadip3– ligand, O9 from water molecule and N2 from bpy ligand. Ni2 is located at an inversion center. In addition to two oxygen atoms (O10, O10A) from two equivalent trans-related water molecules (for symmetry codes, see Figure ), Ni2 is ligated by two equivalent nitrogen atoms from two different bpy ligands and two oxygen atoms from the iminocarbxylate arms of two different Hadip3– ligands. As a result, Ni1 and Ni2 are linked together via a syn-anti carboxylate bridge (O3–C10–O14) with the distance (5.337 Å) between Ni1 and Ni2. Each Hadip3– ligand is not fully deprotonated and carries one proton on one isophthalic oxygen O7. The protonation site is supported by the C–O bond lengths: C8–O7 and C8–O8 are 1.297 (5) Å and 1.224 (6) Å, respectively. Four equivalent asymmetric units at {x, y, z}, {1 – x, 1 – y, –z}, {x– 1/2, 1/2 + y, z}, and {3/2 – x, 1/2 – y, –z} form a secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a). The SBU can be described as a grid composed of two approximate rectangles in possession of the same point. The long side of the parallelogram is built up by the bpy ligand, while the short one is built up by one bridging carboxylate group of the iminodiacetate moiety. The two adjacent SBUs are linked by two equivalent Hadip3– ligands along the short side and propagate along the long side in two different directions. The torsion angle between the adjacent SBUs (Ni1Ni2–Ni2Ni1) is 56.555(4)°. The SBUs are alternatively arranged in two different directions forming a 1D X-shaped chain. In a chain, one kind of SBUs with the same arrangement connects the two neighboring chains (up and down) forming a 2D layer structure. The remaining SBUs in another direction link the layers into a 3D architecture (Figure c). The weak intramolecule π–π stacking between the phenyl rings of the Hadip3– ligands in the adjacent layers further stabilizes the structure. The oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules except O11 are disordered and fill in the channels of the framework.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction study indicates that complex 3 crystallizes in a triclinic P1̅ space group. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit consists of four crystallographically independent Ni(II) ions, two types of adip4– ligands (La and Lb), nine coordinated water molecules, half of a bpy ligand, and five guest water molecules. The four nickel centers are six-coordinated and located in different coordination environments. The Ni1, Ni3, Ni4 are surrounded by an octahedron of NO5, with Ni2 in an octahedron of O6. La and Lb adopt two different coordination modes A and B, respectively (Scheme ). Ni1 is chelated by the flexible iminodiacetate moiety of Lb and is bridged to Ni3 by one carboxylate group through anti-anti mode. Ni2 and Ni4 are linked to a dinuclear unit by a μ2-bridging water molecule and the carboxylic bridge (O11–C14–O12) of La through a syn-anti mode. The two independent metal–metal distance within this dinuclear is 3.717 Å. The flexible iminodiacetate moiety of La chelates the Ni3 and bridges Ni3 and Ni4 together via a syn-anti carboxylate bridge mode. The residual coordination positions of the four metal centers are occupied by water molecules except that the nitrogen donor (N3) binds to Ni4. As a result, the adip4– ligands connect the metal centers into a 2D ladderlike layer and the bpy ligands pillar the layers to form a 3D architecture (Figure a). Free water molecules occupy the void of the framework, where one water molecule oxygen atom (O31 and O31′) is disordered.

elements.content: The topology of 3 is analyzed to best understand the structure. The dinuclear unit of Ni2 and Ni4 metal centers is simplified to a five-connected node. The isophthalate moiety of the adip4– and the iminodiacetate group involving the metal cations (Ni1 and Ni3) chelated by them are regarded as three-connected nodes. The Schläfli symbol of 3 is (4.6.8)4(62.86.102) (Figure b), and such (3,5)-connected topology has not been reported in the literature.

elements.content: The single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in a tetragonal P41212 chiral space group, which has been obtained by spontaneous resolution from the achiral ligand. As illustrated in Figure , the structure of 4 contains two independent Ni(II) cations (Ni1 and Ni2), one bpp ligand, and one adip4– ligand in the asymmetrical unit. Ni1 and Ni2 cations both possess typical six-coordinated octahedron geometries. Each adip4– ligand in complex 4 is fully deprotonated and adopts coordinate mode D to connect six metal centers (Scheme ). For Ni1, three carboxylic oxygen atoms from different adip4– ligands occupy three face-related sites, while the other three coordination sites are afforded by two water molecules and one nitrogen atom from bpp ligand. For Ni2, the metal center is chelated by the iminodiacetate functionality of one adip4– ligand, and the remaining coordination sites are occupied by two oxygen atoms from the other two individual adip4– ligands and by one nitrogen atom of another bpp ligand. In the asymmetrical unit, Ni1 and Ni2 form a dinuclear SBU, in which two bidentate carboxylic groups from the isophthalate moieties of the two different adip4– ligands and a carboxylicμ2-O from the iminodiacetate functionality of another adip4– ligand bridge Ni1 and Ni2 together. The nonbonding metal–metal distances within the dinuclear cluster are 3.453 Å. These dinuclear SBUs are linked by carboxylic groups of the isophthalate moiety to give a right-handed 41 helical chain with a pitch of 18.6518 (9) Å along the crystallographic c-axis (Figure a), while one carboxylic group of the isophthalate moiety and the iminodiacetate functionality from one H4adip4– ligand link the SBUs to form two kinds of right-handed helical chains (Figure b,c). With a pitch of 17.6574 (4) Å, the helical chains winding around a 2-fold screw axis run parallel to the a-axis and b-axis, respectively. The three kinds of helical chains above are joined together through another group of adip4– ligands. As a result, the adip4– ligands join the SBUs into a 3D homochiral framework. By reduction of each adip4– ligand and SBU as a three-connected node, such a structure can be topologically represented as a 3-connected net containing zigzag helical chains (Figure d), which possesses a 103 topological characteristic. The open space of the framework leads to the formation of two kinds of helical chains linked by bpp ligands between SBUs. The bpp ligands with the TT conformation bridge the SBUs winding around a 2-fold screw axis. With a pitch of 24.9713(8), the two helical chains form two helical tubes along [110] and [11̅0] directions with the point of inversion situated in the center of the adjacent 2-fold screw axis (Figure e). This results in a complex 3D metal–organic framework with a (4.52)(4.53.72.84) topology (Figure f). It is noted that the (3,5)-connected topological net is a new topology.

elements.content: Interestingly, the chiral structure of complex 4 is obtained from achiral reagents by spontaneous resolution. Since the first spontaneous resolution was discovered by Pasteur in 1848, chemists have devoted effort to the construction of chiral architectures through spontaneous resolution from chiral or achiral species. Spontaneous resolution is still a scarce phenomenon because the laws of physics determining the processes are still a mystery. Complex 4 and its enantiomer crystallize together and compose a racemic mixture, which can be supported by the lack of a signal of the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectrum (Figure S6, ).

elements.content: Initially, the H4adip as the exclusive ligand reacts with the Ni(II) salt generating a 2D layer structure for complex 1. To control the assembly process and modulate the present structure, the auxiliary ligands bpy and bpp are introduced. If the coordinated water molecules in 1 are removed, the empty place between the neighboring layers would remain and the coordination sites of the layers could be offered for the auxiliary ligands. Since the shortest distances of the Ni3···Ni3 centers and Ni4···Ni4 centers between the adjacent layers are 10.4291 and 10.9430 Å, respectively, which are close to the length of the bpy ligand, a 3D framework (complex 3) containing similar layers is obtained. Here, the bpy ligands in 3 take the place of the coordinated water molecules and link the neighboring layers. The preparation of 2 is similar to that of 3 except in the absence of the sodium hydroxide, resulting the partially deprotonated Hadip3– ligands. With this discrepancy, complex 2 does not show a framework similar to 3; instead, another new 3D structure formed. Unfortunately, complex 2 cannot convert into complex 3 by introduction of the sodium hydroxide into the solution of 2 in the hydrothermal condition or at room temperature. In the reaction of 4, a half-flexible ligand bpp is used. Belonging to the same kind of bridge ligands in a certain sense, the figuration and function of bpy and bpp are quite similar. Nevertheless, according calculations, the length of the bpp ligand does not match the distance between the layers in 3, which suggests that complex 4 is difficult to generate a similar framework as 3. Hence, 4 is an achiral 3D structure with helical chains, in which the half-flexible ligand bpp adjusts its configuration to link the SBUs into a high dimensional framework. Here, conformational flexibility of bpp is probably the main factor to induce the formation of the helices and achiral structure of 4. It is obvious that the length and configuration of the auxiliary ligands play an important role in the final results.

Effects of Base and Auxiliary Ligands

Initially, the H4adip as the exclusive ligand reacts with the Ni(II) salt generating a 2D layer structure for complex 1. To control the assembly process and modulate the present structure, the auxiliary ligands bpy and bpp are introduced. If the coordinated water molecules in 1 are removed, the empty place between the neighboring layers would remain and the coordination sites of the layers could be offered for the auxiliary ligands. Since the shortest distances of the Ni3⋅⋅⋅Ni3 centers and Ni4⋅⋅⋅Ni4 centers between the adjacent layers are 10.4291 and 10.9430 Å, respectively, which are close to the length of the bpy ligand, a 3D framework (complex 3) containing similar layers is obtained. Here, the bpy ligands in 3 take the place of the coordinated water molecules and link the neighboring layers. The preparation of 2 is similar to that of 3 except in the absence of the sodium hydroxide, resulting the partially deprotonated Hadip3- ligands. With this discrepancy, complex 2 does not show a framework similar to 3; instead, another new 3D structure formed. Unfortunately, complex 2 cannot convert into complex 3 by introduction of the sodium hydroxide into the solution of 2 in the hydrothermal condition or at room temperature. In the reaction of 4, a half-flexible ligand bpp is used. Belonging to the same kind of bridge ligands in a certain sense, the figuration and function of bpy and bpp are quite similar. Nevertheless, according calculations, the length of the bpp ligand does not match the distance between the layers in 3, which suggests that complex 4 is difficult to generate a similar framework as 3. Hence, 4 is an achiral 3D structure with helical chains, in which the half-flexible ligand bpp adjusts its configuration to link the SBUs into a high dimensional framework. Here, conformational flexibility of bpp is probably the main factor to induce the formation of the helices and achiral structure of 4. It is obvious that the length and configuration of the auxiliary ligands play an important role in the final results.

elements.content: To investigate the exact number of the free water molecules and thermal stability of the complexes, the thermal weight measurements are carried out in the range of 30–800 °C (Figure ). Complex 1 loses all the free water molecules and eight aqua ligands in the range of 30–300 °C (calculated: 22.7%, found: 22.6%). From 300 to 370 °C, it loses the rest of two coordination water molecules and begins to decompose (calculated: 3.3%, found: 3.2%). Complex 2 loses all the free water molecules and coordination water molecules around 250 °C (calculated: 17.9%, found: 18.0%), and the following thermal behavior is ascribed to the decomposition of the complex. For complex 3, the loss of all the water molecules occurs from 30 to 220 °C (calculated: 21.9%, found: 21.7%). The framework of 3 begins to collapse around 350 °C after a smooth decrease of the weight from 220 to 350 °C. For complex 4, the weight loss in the range of 30–300 °C corresponds to the departure of three lattice water molecules and two coordinated aqua molecules (calculated: 10.6%, found: 11.1%) and then the framework undergoes decomposition in the range of 300–400 °C.

Thermal Analyses

To investigate the exact number of the free water molecules and thermal stability of the complexes, the thermal weight measurements are carried out in the range of 30-800 °C (Figure ). Complex 1 loses all the free water molecules and eight aqua ligands in the range of 30-300 °C (calculated: 22.7%, found: 22.6%). From 300 to 370 °C, it loses the rest of two coordination water molecules and begins to decompose (calculated: 3.3%, found: 3.2%). Complex 2 loses all the free water molecules and coordination water molecules around 250 °C (calculated: 17.9%, found: 18.0%), and the following thermal behavior is ascribed to the decomposition of the complex. For complex 3, the loss of all the water molecules occurs from 30 to 220 °C (calculated: 21.9%, found: 21.7%). The framework of 3 begins to collapse around 350 °C after a smooth decrease of the weight from 220 to 350 °C. For complex 4, the weight loss in the range of 30-300 °C corresponds to the departure of three lattice water molecules and two coordinated aqua molecules (calculated: 10.6%, found: 11.1%) and then the framework undergoes decomposition in the range of 300-400 °C.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 3 are measured on crystalline samples under 1000 Oe in the range of 2–300 K. Their χM and χM T versus T plots (χM is the magnetic susceptibilities per one formula unit) are shown in Figure . The χM T values of 5.10 and 5.14 cm–3 K mol–1 for 1 and 3, respectively, are approximately equal due to the metal cations of the two structures in almost identical coordination environments, which are in good agreement with the four isolated Ni(II) ions (S = 1, expected for g = 2.26). As the temperature decreases, both the χM T values decrease slowly between 300 and 50 K and then decrease more steeply down to the minimums at 2 K. The 1/χM vs T plots follow the Curie–Weiss law with C = 5.13 cm–3 K mol–1, θ = −6.01 K for 1 and C = 5.22 cm–3 K mol–1, θ = −9.58 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The above features all indicate antiferromagnetic interaction between the Ni(II) centers.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 3 are measured on crystalline samples under 1000 Oe in the range of 2-300 K. Their χM and χM T versus T plots (χM is the magnetic susceptibilities per one formula unit) are shown in Figure . The χM T values of 5.10 and 5.14 cm-3 K mol-1 for 1 and 3, respectively, are approximately equal due to the metal cations of the two structures in almost identical coordination environments, which are in good agreement with the four isolated Ni(II) ions (S = 1, expected for g = 2.26). As the temperature decreases, both the χM T values decrease slowly between 300 and 50 K and then decrease more steeply down to the minimums at 2 K. The 1/χM vs T plots follow the Curie-Weiss law with C = 5.13 cm-3 K mol-1, θ = -6.01 K for 1 and C = 5.22 cm-3 K mol-1, θ = -9.58 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The above features all indicate antiferromagnetic interaction between the Ni(II) centers.

elements.content: The interactions among the binuclear units and the other two Ni(II) centers are ignored considering the long distance among them. On the basis of the binuclear model, the Hamiltonian for the binuclear unit (Ni2 and Ni4) is Ĥ = −J(Ŝ b 2 – Ŝ 2 2 – Ŝ 4 2), where Ŝ b is the total spin of the binuclear unit. From the application of the van Vleck equation, the magnetic susceptibility in the μB H/kT≪1 approximation is given by the expression: χ ′ M T = 2 N g 2 β 2 k e 2 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T 1 + 3 e 2 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T

elements.content: The best fit for complex 1 is obtained for J/k = −5.69 K and g = 2.24. For complex 3, the best fit is obtained for J/k = −11.13 K and g = 2.26. The difference between the two values of the J/k is attributed to the distance change between the metal centers of the binuclear units. The metal–metal distances in the dinulcear unit for complexes 1 and 3 are 3.666 and 3.717 Å, respectively. As the distance increases, the antiferromagnetic interactions become stronger.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 2 and 4 are also studied () from 300 to 2 K at 1000 Oe. The room-temperature χM T values of 2.26 cm–3 K mol–1 and 2.83 cm–3 K mol–1 for 2 and 4, respectively, are much larger than the spin-only values of 2.26 cm–3 K mol–1 for one and half uncoupled Ni(II) ions and 2.83 cm–3 K mol–1 for two uncoupled Ni(II) ions with a significant contribution from the unquenched orbital momentum in the octahedral field. As the temperature is lowered, the χM T values continuously decrease. This behavior is indicative of the antiferromagnetic interaction for the two complexes.

elements.content: Four nickel(II)-5-aminodiacetic isophthalate complexes have been synthesized by modulating the configuration and length of the N-donor auxiliary ligands. The coordination sites offered by the layers for the auxiliary ligands are the curial factors to form the pillared layered structures. The linear coligands can be the preferential candidates to pillar the present layers, and their length and configuration play an important role in the final structures. The auxiliary ligands with appropriate length and configuration may facilitate the construction of the desired structures and offer a new approach to construct novel MOFs in the near future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four nickel(II)-5-aminodiacetic isophthalate complexes have been synthesized by modulating the configuration and length of the N-donor auxiliary ligands. The coordination sites offered by the layers for the auxiliary ligands are the curial factors to form the pillared layered structures. The linear coligands can be the preferential candidates to pillar the present layers, and their length and configuration play an important role in the final structures. The auxiliary ligands with appropriate length and configuration may facilitate the construction of the desired structures and offer a new approach to construct novel MOFs in the near future.

A mixture of H4adip (0.2 mmol, 60 mg), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 297 mg), NaOH (0.2 mmol, 8 mg), THF (5 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 120 °C, and held at the temperature for 96 h. The autoclave was allowed to cool to 30 °C for 24 h. Pale green crystals of complex 1 were collected in 65.2% yield based on H4adip. Anal. Calcd for C24H24N3O12Ni2 (M r = 663.79): C, 25.96%; H, 4.14%; N, 2.52%. Found: C, 25.80%; H, 4.22%; N, 2.35%. cln_elements.content:
To investigate the exact number of the free water molecules and thermal stability of the complexes, the thermal weight measurements are carried out in the range of 30–800 °C (Figure ). Complex 1 loses all the free water molecules and eight aqua ligands in the range of 30–300 °C (calculated: 22.7%, found: 22.6%). From 300 to 370 °C, it loses the rest of two coordination water molecules and begins to decompose (calculated: 3.3%, found: 3.2%). Complex 2 loses all the free water molecules and coordination water molecules around 250 °C (calculated: 17.9%, found: 18.0%), and the following thermal behavior is ascribed to the decomposition of the complex. For complex 3, the loss of all the water molecules occurs from 30 to 220 °C (calculated: 21.9%, found: 21.7%). The framework of 3 begins to collapse around 350 °C after a smooth decrease of the weight from 220 to 350 °C. For complex 4, the weight loss in the range of 30–300 °C corresponds to the departure of three lattice water molecules and two coordinated aqua molecules (calculated: 10.6%, found: 11.1%) and then the framework undergoes decomposition in the range of 300–400 °C.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 3 are measured on crystalline samples under 1000 Oe in the range of 2–300 K. Their χM and χM T versus T plots (χM is the magnetic susceptibilities per one formula unit) are shown in Figure . The χM T values of 5.10 and 5.14 cm–3 K mol–1 for 1 and 3, respectively, are approximately equal due to the metal cations of the two structures in almost identical coordination environments, which are in good agreement with the four isolated Ni(II) ions (S = 1, expected for g = 2.26). As the temperature decreases, both the χM T values decrease slowly between 300 and 50 K and then decrease more steeply down to the minimums at 2 K. The 1/χM vs T plots follow the Curie–Weiss law with C = 5.13 cm–3 K mol–1, θ = −6.01 K for 1 and C = 5.22 cm–3 K mol–1, θ = −9.58 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The above features all indicate antiferromagnetic interaction between the Ni(II) centers.
